awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4:NSF: The Epistemology of Agricultural Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description: 
Philosophers of science analyze the logical and conceptual foundations (i.e. the epistemologies) of scientific knowledge. Epistemologies of science elucidate why and how science works. Understanding the nature of science enables philosophers and scientists to work together to improve scientific methods and further scientific progress, as well as to employ science to improve the welfare of the nation and the world. This EPSCoR Research Fellowship will produce the first analysis of the epistemology of agricultural science. Agricultural science is an interdisciplinary and applied set of scientific practices that will feature prominently in solutions to urgent, global 21st-century problems, including the energy crisis and food shortages anticipated by climate change. Understanding the epistemology of agricultural science will improve the abilities of scientists and policymakers to employ the results of agricultural science to solve large-scale social problems.  The PI and a postdoctoral scholar will collect field data, receive additional training members in science and values, and strengthen an existing research collaboration at Michigan State University, to advance the PI’s research on the epistemology of agricultural science.

Technical Description:
This EPSCoR Research Fellowship will fund a research residency for the PI and a postdoctoral scholar to collect field data, receive additional training, and strengthen an existing research collaboration at Michigan State University (MSU), in order to advance the PI’s research on the epistemology of agricultural science. The Fellowship is co-sponsored by the MSU Department of Philosophy, the MSU Socially Engaged Philosophy of Science (SEPOS) group, and the MSU Center for Interdisciplinarity. The overall objective of the Fellowship is to accelerate research in the epistemology of agricultural science by strengthening the research partnership between philosophers at the University of Kentucky and MSU. This will be accomplished via two types of research activity: 1) Collaborative philosophical research with members of the sponsoring institutes.  The PI and postdoc will additionally receive training from SEPOS members in science and values, a branch of philosophy of science for which MSU and SEPOS are widely renowned; and 2) Collection of data from philosophical fieldwork on the agricultural scientific activity being conducted at MSU. The PI employs fieldwork methods to conduct research, including interviewing and shadowing practicing agricultural scientists to examine how they generate concepts and theoretical frameworks. Due to the localized nature of agricultural science, comparative data across multiple locations, e.g. Kentucky and Michigan, is required. Analysis of applied science, especially agricultural science, innovates on the way epistemology of science understands the nature of the scientific practice. This advances inquiry in the epistemology of science, particularly impacting existing research in the philosophy of scientific classification and the study of science and values. This Fellowship will expand the scope of philosophy of science, and, via the collection of field data, it will also generate a dataset that will catalyze additional new scholarship in the epistemology of science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award produced the first modern, systematic, philosophical investigation of scientific reasoning in agricultural science, focusing primarily on cropping practices in Michigan. The research team employed philosophical, historical, and social-scientific methods in order to map the complex network of technological, biological, physical, social, institutional, governmental, and economic factors affecting the design of modern agriculture and the scientific research that supports it. Members of the research team conducted interviews, extended observation, archival research, and philosophical analysis to obtain results.

 

Intellectual Merit: Key finding 1. Agricultural science is meliorative. Unlike some areas of the sciences, which aim to describe and characterize aspects of the world as it is, meliorative sciences conduct research with the explicit or implicit aim of improving some aspect of the world. Typically, “improvement” is defined relative to human interests. Medical scientific research is meliorative, aiming not simply to understand human health but to improve it; our team found that agricultural science is importantly analogous. The aims and epistemic structures of medical science are well-studied in the philosophy of science, and insight from those findings can be used to inform future research into the philosophy of agricultural science.

 

Key finding 2. A complex network of professionals and content experts who are not trained scientists play essential roles in defining the goals, methods, and measures of success in agricultural scientific research (ASR). ASR experiments are frequently conducted on commercial farms, monitored and maintained through crop development by farm workers as opposed to scientists or laboratory technicians. This is a unique type of scientific activity that sets ASR apart from most other forms of contemporary experimental research. The role of extension workers from county agents to university faculty members adds further complexity to this picture, particularly in the mechanisms by which ASR experiments are defined in response to commercial- and community-reported problems in production. Further, industry is deeply integrated into ASR in ways that impact research agendas. This integration does not directly parallel industry integration in medical/pharmaceutical research, and requires further epistemic analysis.

 

This key finding holds a number of implications for philosophy of science (PS). Notably, it complicates standard PS stories about the epistemic roles of non-scientists in the production of scientific knowledge, offering an alternative to standard citizen-scientist accounts. Similar complications arise for industry. It also generates a challenge to the standard PS assumption that products of scientific research are separable from producers of research. 

 

Key finding 3. The products of ASR are best characterized and classified through endemic classificatory schemes, rather than by extending biological or economic classification practices. This finding is best understood by example. Consider potatoes: the biological taxonomy of potatoes is well-established as solanum tuberosum. This classification embeds important scientific information about the lifecycle of potatoes and their connections to biological relatives in the nightshade family, and it can be used to draw inferences about many other topics of interest, such as the geographic history of potato plants. The biological taxonomy of potatoes cannot, however, inform many important aspects of ASR, such as research on potato storage or optimal sugar–starch ratios for chipping. Instead, agricultural classification systems that distinguish finer-grained differences between potato types (e.g. cultivars) must be implemented in order to achieve the meliorative aims of many ASR experiments. These classification systems operate on features of potatoes that are not considered to be biologically significant to solanum tuberosum as a species, but which are nonetheless deeply significant to the agricultural uses to which grown potatoes will be put.

 

Broader Impacts: STEM workforce. Grant activities provided essential training in cutting-edge research methods for all members of the research team. Team members trained in interview methods, archival methods, and philosophical methods that advanced members’ ability to perform research and, in that case of two junior researchers, led directly to further career opportunities. In one case, a junior researcher previously trained as a philosopher of science became sufficiently proficient in interview and data analysis methods to receive employment as a social scientist with the USDA. In another case, a junior researcher previously trained as a historian of science had work accepted for presentation at two competitive philosophy of science conferences.

 

Inclusion. The research team consisted of 6 central researchers. The three seniormost team members each fall into at least one recognized category of minorities underrepresented in STEM. One of the junior team members falls into a recognized category of minorities underrepresented in STEM. Through efforts associated with grant activity, this team member was also placed in a competitive postdoctoral opportunity that would not have been available without their participation in grant activities.

 

Partnerships. By highlighting and analyzing the role of industry in the production of ASR findings, this research strengthens understanding of how to efficiently, effectively, and ethically partner with industry in the production of ASR.
